Henry Gilligan
Just a Christian. · Author has 7.4K answers and 2.5M answer views · Dec 26 ·

I hope you realize that there was no Christian Church when Jesus died. Jesus was a Jew who lived in Israel. He came to His own Jewish people as their Messiah and King. But Christians were not call “Christians” until years after Jesus’ death and resurrection (see Acts 11:26). The curtain that tore was in the Jewish temple, and God tore it to represent that man through Christ now has full access to God. Priests and sacrificial rituals are no longer needed. Thus, the separation between the Holy Place in the Temple from the Most Holy Place (Holy of Holies) was no longer needed.

Who were the chief priests that felt threatened by Jesus during His time?

Annas, his son-in-law Caiaphas, and their clan and associates. The family of Annas monopolized the High Priesthood for over seventy years. It was the family business, a lucrative racket in fact.

When Jesus cleansed the Temple of the money-changers and animal sellers it was a direct assault on their control of the Temple and the profits it won them.

Just to explain some of their money-making activities.

Roman or Greek or other coins bearing images of Caesar etc were not legal currency in the Temple. So pilgrims had to exchange their ordinary money for Temple shekels, at poor rates of exchange and high commission rates.

Animals brought for sacrifice needed a kosher certificate to guarantee that they were free from blemish or disease. The Temple animal inspectors were adept at finding fault with the pilgrim’s offerings.

The pilgrims would then have to buy “kosher” certificated animals at vastly inflated prices from the salesmen within the Temple. Mangy specimens too. But they had the certificate.

So profits all round, and big commissions for Annas & Co who held the franchise. Just the poor pilgrims, who might have saved up for years for a once-in-a-lifetime pilgrimage to Jerusalem, got well and truly ripped off at every turn.

Who was high priest at the time of Jesus, what did he do, and when and how did he die?

Annas and Caiaphas are two high priests mentioned during Jesus’ public ministry (Luke 3:2). In that period of history, high priests were installed and removed by Roman rulers. The position of High Priest was basically given to the highest bidder. The appointment to High Priest was for sale and money was paid to Rome to be appointed to the position as was the case with Annas. Caiaphas was Annas son

Annas and Caiaphas are two high priests mentioned during Jesus’ public ministry (Luke 3:2). In that period of history, high priests were installed and removed by Roman rulers. The position of High Priest was basically given to the highest bidder. The appointment to High Priest was for sale and money was paid to Rome to be appointed to the position as was the case with Annas. Caiaphas was Annas son in law.

“And led him away to Annas first; for he was father in law to Caiaphas, which was the high priest that same year.” John 18:13

While it is not recorded in the Bible, the tradition is that the Romans had deposed Annas and made Caiaphas the high priest. So, officially, Caiaphas, the son-in-law of Annas, was high priest during Jesus’ ministry, but Annas, the former high priest, still held significant sway and was still called a high priest (John 18:13).

The High Priest was a corrupt position, it was customary for people to purchase a dove on the street and brig it into the synagogue as a sacrifice. The priest would examine the dove only to find a blemish on the bird and reject it as an offering, its at this point the priest would point out the doves that already in the synagogue that were acceptable as sacrifices, but these doves cost $10–$15 dollars rather than (.20) twenty cents, which is why Jesus was angry and drove out the money changers from the synagogue. They were taking advantage of the people and turned something holy into a monetary exercise. Annas owned this business in the synagogues and Jesus actions sparked what would become a personal grudge for Annas about Jesus.

“And Jesus went into the temple of God, and cast out all them that sold and bought in the temple, and overthrew the tables of the moneychangers, and the seats of them that sold doves, And said unto them, It is written, My house shall be called the house of prayer; but ye have made it a den of thieves.” Matthew 21:1–13

When Jesus was arrested in Gethsemane, He was brought before Annas to be questioned (John 18:13; 19–23). Annas sent Him to Caiaphas (John 18:24). The Sanhedrin was also involved in this questioning (Matthew 26:57). Jesus was led away from Caiaphas’ house to stand before Pilate (John 18:28), who then sent Jesus to Herod (Luke 23:6–7), who returned Him to Pilate (Luke 23:11).

Pilate did not want to condemn Jesus, he spoke with Jesus privately in order to learn His side John 18:33–40

Pilate eventually condemned Jesus to death by crucifixion, after declaring Him innocent three times (John 18:38; 19:4, 6).

Jesus’ trial before Annas and Caiaphas was marked by false testimony and conflicting reports of what Jesus had done and said (Mark 14:56). Pilate in an attempt to free Jesus, ordered Jesus scourged with 39 lashes using a cat of nine tails. 40 represents judgment while 39 means mercy, judgement was to be tempered with mercy, therefore the standard sentence was 39 lashes.

When the centurions flogged a man, it was tradition that while the man was beaten with the cat of nine tails, the prisoner would confess their crimes. As a result of the confessions, each lash was given with less force as long as the prisoner continued to confess their crimes until the last lash, which at that point would be gently laid on the back.

In most cases, even with milder and milder strokes of the lash, the man would die from blood loss. In the case of Jesus, He did not say a word throughout the ordeal. When He was brought back to Pliate, the prefect knew that Jesus had not uttered a word signifying His innocence. “Jesus remained silent and gave no answer” (verse 61).

Caiaphas began to despair of finding enough evidence to put Jesus to death, but then he asked Him directly, “Are you the Messiah, the Son of the Blessed One?” (verse 61). Jesus answered, “I am. . . . And you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the Mighty One and coming on the clouds of heaven” (verse 62). At this, Caiaphas tore his clothes, decreed Jesus to be a blasphemer, and turned Him over to a mob who beat Him (verses 63–65).

Annas and Caiaphas are also mentioned in Acts 4:6 when Peter and John were questioned before the Jewish rulers: “Annas the high priest was there, and so were Caiaphas, John, Alexander and others of the high priest’s family.” Filled with the Holy Spirit, Peter responded boldly. He gave credit to Jesus Christ of Nazareth for the healing of a lame man (Acts 3:1–1...

How large was the veil or curtain that tore at Jesus' death?

Josephus, a Jewish historian and former priest at the temple, describes the curtain in exquisite detail, saying that it was the same size as the door, being fifty five cubits high and sixteen cubits wide (Jewish Wars.5.4.5):

But then this house, as it was divided into two parts, the inner part was lower than the appearance of the outer, and had golden doors of fifty-five cubits altitude, and sixteen in breadth; but before these doors there was a veil of equal largeness with the doors. It was a Babylonian curtain, embroidered with blue, and fine linen, and scarlet, and purple, and of a contextur

Josephus, a Jewish historian and former priest at the temple, describes the curtain in exquisite detail, saying that it was the same size as the door, being fifty five cubits high and sixteen cubits wide (Jewish Wars.5.4.5):

But then this house, as it was divided into two parts, the inner part was lower than the appearance of the outer, and had golden doors of fifty-five cubits altitude, and sixteen in breadth; but before these doors there was a veil of equal largeness with the doors. It was a Babylonian curtain, embroidered with blue, and fine linen, and scarlet, and purple, and of a contexture that was truly wonderful. Nor was this mixture of colors without its mystical interpretation, but was a kind of image of the universe; for by the scarlet there seemed to be enigmatically signified fire, by the fine flax the earth, by the blue the air, and by the purple the sea; two of them having their colors the foundation of this resemblance; but the fine flax and the purple have their own origin for that foundation, the earth producing the one, and the sea the other. This curtain had also embroidered upon it all that was mystical in the heavens, excepting that of the [twelve] signs, representing living creatures.

Definitions of a cubit varied, but if we use 50 cm as being approximately 1 cubit, the curtain was about 25 metres high and 8 metres wide. From Josephus’ description, it must have been an awe-inspiring sight. Notice that in spite of the considerable detail in which he describes the curtain, there is no mention of any tear to the curtain, nor of any major repair.

There were no Christian priests in the Christian Church while the Jerusalem Temple was still standing. The earliest Christians were almost all Jewish, and they understood that all the priests at the time were Jewish priests serving in the Temple. In addition, the curtain tore during Christ's Crucifixion, before the Christian Church even got its official start on the Day of Pentecost.

The Jerusalem Temple was destroyed by the Romans in AD 70. From this point on, a “Christian priesthood" (separate from and above the run-of-the-mill believer) was conceivable. But it wasn't until the Roman Catholic Church was established in the 4th century that “priests" began to surface.

Biblical Christianity states that ALL believers are priests, which in itself is rather odd, because biblical Christianity also states that priests are no longer necessary! The Roman Catholic Church says otherwise: only male Roman Catholics, who after many years of seminary study, and who are then officially ordained, can be priests. Roman Catholic doctrine also states that priests are critical to the Christian faith.

So the answer to your question is a resounding “NO!”

Will the Vatican ever allow married Catholic priests?

This is a common question, and is unaware of several things. Currently, the “standard issue” Latin Rite priest makes a promise of celibacy at his ordination to Holy Orders, and because the Latin Rite is the largest rite of the Catholic Church people assume that there are no married priests. However, even in the Latin Rite (which has standardized the discipline of celibacy for priests for 1,000 years), married men are sometimes allowed to be ordained in special exceptions, and in the Anglican Ordinariate (part of the Catholic Church, basically, but with Anglican heritage) married priests are common. In the Eastern Rites of the Catholic Church (and in the Eastern Churches), married priests are commonplace.

In both the East and the West, since the beginning, however, men who have been ordained cannot remarry. Even those who are married priests cannot, if their wife dies, remarry.

So, “will the Vatican ever allow [it]?” It already does. As to the widespread abandonment of the practice of celibacy, this is unlikely but possible.

When I was 19 years old, I was in a really bad place. I had been working in the library at my University, and I had suffered a bad fall- I injured my back pretty severely. Now, I ended up only requiring the aid of a cane, but I was lucky- I was told that I’d likely need to use crutches for the rest of my life, or possibly even a wheelchair. I was not okay with this.

I was already a drug user, I had been for years. So I went home and I popped a handful of Xanax, a handful of Vicodin, and washed it down with a fifth of Vodka. I put on some cartoons and waited to die.

I woke up in the hospital. I have no idea how, and I have no memory of doing this, but apparently at some point I had wandered out onto my front lawn before passing out, somebody had found me and called an ambulance. When I was in that ambulance, my heart stopped. I was clinically dead for almost four minutes.

But here I am, writing this answer now. So, yes, people can come back to life after death.

What temple was destroyed when Jesus died?

No temple was destroyed when Jesus died, but the Jerusalem temple was destroyed at about the time the first gospel was written—Mark’s Gospel. In hindsight, Mark has Jesus prophesy the destruction of the temple and then his return on clouds of glory within the lifetimes of those to whom he spoke.

Were priests known as rabbis in the time of Jesus?

“Cohen” means “Priest” - that is someone who offers sacrifices in the Temple in Jerusalem. “Rabbi” literally means “Great One”, and is a respectful way to address a teacher. One place you would expect to find a teacher would be in a synagogue - a house of prayer and study.

“Cohen” means “Priest” - that is someone who offers sacrifices in the Temple in Jerusalem. “Rabbi” literally means “Great One”, and is a respectful way to address a teacher. One place you would expect to find a teacher would be in a synagogue - a house of prayer and study.

In the year 70, the Temple in Jerusalem was destroyed - this ended the era of the Second Temple (the first Temple was the one destroyed by the Babylonians, the Second Temple was destroyed by the Romans). Under the leadership of Rabbi Yohannan ben Zakkai the town of Yavne emerged as the new centre for the Jewish religion. But rather than rebuilding the Temple, study of the Torah took the place of offering sacrifice in the Temple. This is the start of the period of Rabbinic Judaism.

Would there be no church and no temple without Christ's priesthood?

Collect:

“O God, who for the glory of your majesty and the salvation of the human race, made your Only Begotten Son the Eternal High Priest, grant that, those whom he has chosen as ministers and stewards of his mysteries may be found faithful in carrying out the ministry they have received.”

Feast of Our Lord Jesus Christ, Eternal High Priest

There would be no Church and no temple without Christ’s Priesthood.

The sacrifices of the Old Law, those of the patriarchs, and those of the Temple of Jerusalem by the priests, were far from perfect; sheep and goats were unworthy offering to God in acknowledgement of His power and glory. These imperfect sacrifices were simply types and figures of Christ’s Most Perfect Sacrifice of Himself as Victim on the Cross to His Father in Heaven.

In the times of the Old Law of the Jews, this is the reason why God promised that He would institute a new sacrifice, a perfect sacrifice, an unblemished victim.

In the words of the prophet Malachi:

“From the rising of the sun even to the going down, my name is great among the Gentiles, and in every place there is sacrifice, and there is offered to my name a clean oblation.” (St. Malachi I:10–11)

These prophetic words refer to the Sacrifice of the Mass, in which the Victim is Jesus Christ the Son of God, in Whom there can be no worthier, no purer, no more perfect sacrifice.

The Catholic Church has always taught that the Holy Mass is a true sacrifice.

St. Paul implies this when he says:

“We have an altar from which they have no right to eat who serve the tabernacle (meaning the Jews).” (Hebrews XIII:10)

The prophet Malachi foretold the universality of the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass. Since there are Catholic priests and churches all over the world, this prophecy is today accomplished quite literally, for in all places the “clean oblation,” Holy Mass, is offered to God alone.

Jesus Christ, Our Lord, said the first Mass, at the Last Supper, the night before He died.

At the Last Supper, Our Divine Redeemer offered Himself up as a Perfect Sacrifice to the Eternal Father under the appearances of bread and wine. (St. Mark XIV:22–25)

The following day Jesus Christ consummated that Sacrifice by freely subjecting Himself to His Passion and Death by crucifixion at the hands of the Jews.

There were two acts: the first act was at the Last Supper, and the second act was on the Cross at Calvary; two acts of the one supreme sacrifice of Christ to His Father. After the first act, Our Lord said: “Do this in remembrance of me.” (St. Luke XXII:19) By these words, Our Savior told His Apostles to do as He had done, offer in sacrifice to God His Sacred Body and Blood, really, yet sacramentally, present under the appearances of bread and wine; Jesus Christ commanded them in those words to say Mass, as the Perfect Sacrifice to God, within the bosom of our Holy Mother, the Church, that Christ Himself instituted.

The Mass, therefore, is a real sacrifice, for in it a Victim is offered for the purpose of reconciling man with God. Our Lord caused His Passion and Death to enter into the institution of the Mass within His Church, thereby joining the Mass and His Sacrificial Death on the Cross as one.

At the Last Supper, Jesus Christ, Our Divine Savior, evidently meant to institute a visible sacrifice. He chose the act the very time (14 Nisan) when the old sacrifice of the Paschal lamb (another figure of Christ: “Behold the Lamb of God; behold He who taketh away the sins of the world”) was celebrated

In St. John’s Gospel, Our Lord Jesus Christ died on the Day of Preparation (14 Nisan), the day before the Passover meal, sometime after noon but before sunset later that evening. According to the Jewish historian, Josephus, this would have been "from the ninth hour till the eleventh" (3 p.m. to 5 p.m.) (“The Jewish War”, VI.)

The very words used by Christ in instituting the Sacrifice of the Mass, the “New Covenant”, or “New Testament”, were almost identical with those used in the institution of the sacrifice of the Old Law.

It is, therefore, Christ’s Sacred High Priesthood, at the Last Supper, and on the Cross, that unites as one, the figurative sacrifices of the Levite priests of the Temple of Jerusalem of the Old Covenant, with the re-actualized Holy Sacrifice of the Mass, offered “in remembrance of Christ” by Catholic priests of the Church of the New Covenant, everywhere, in every age, until the end of time.

Were early Christian churches built like synagogues?

The early Christians used houses or the catacombs to assemble more or less secretly. When they were legalized and able to build churches (after 313 AD), they tended to use the Roman basilica layout of an oblong hall, with sanctuary at one end.

Synagogues often took a similar form, but by the fourth century the overwhelming majority of Christians were Gentiles, and relations with the diaspora Jews were not good. Christians would have been unlikely to copy Jewish traditions.

The fifth century Santa Sabina, the Dominican church on the Aventine in Rome, is a superb example of the basilica-type archi

The early Christians used houses or the catacombs to assemble more or less secretly. When they were legalized and able to build churches (after 313 AD), they tended to use the Roman basilica layout of an oblong hall, with sanctuary at one end.

Synagogues often took a similar form, but by the fourth century the overwhelming majority of Christians were Gentiles, and relations with the diaspora Jews were not good. Christians would have been unlikely to copy Jewish traditions.

The fifth century Santa Sabina, the Dominican church on the Aventine in Rome, is a superb example of the basilica-type architecture.

Yes. Absolutely. However, one must remember what the word ‘church’ means:

Christ is the Living Temple, and the Church is His embodiment. The best analogy is the one He Himself uses: Jesus serves as the seed from which the True Vine grows. Is the vine equivalent to the seed? Yes and no. Similarly, the seed transmits and communicates the Logos of Life that its temporal form is an incarnation of. This is why God can be born as a baby and why the post-resurrection body of the Lord appears transcendent in its properties. Jesus is meta and physical.

When we realise that Christ acts like an organism that includes elements of its environment into a dynamic form we begin to realise some of the depth of what the apostle Paul implies with his phrase ‘in Christ’. The Church is ‘in Christ’ in the same way that cells are in a body. However, Christ is ‘in the Church’ in the same way that what gives those cells their form and function is both the ‘informative’ Word that summarises the whole form (like DNA in our molecular biology) and the overarching coherent co-operation of tissues which transcends the ‘perspectives’ of the individual participant components.

Hence, Christ is comparable to any Fractal form - being self-similar from ‘bottom-up’ and ‘top-down’. Any human constitution of the Church is necessarily limited in its legitimacy for the same reason that neither brain cells nor blood can correctly characterise ‘the body’ - and this is what Paul explains in 1 Cor 12. It is Christ who defines the Church in every way - just see the letters in John’s apocalyptic vision! - and for this reason He is the Establishment itself; not the human hologram of it, but the Real Thing.

How did Christianity rise after Jesus’ crucifixion?

The information we have about the first few decades and even centuries after Jesus' crucifixion is spotty, but you can get an idea of the story from reading certain sources: the New Testament (especially Acts and the epistles), the writings of the early church fathers, the writings of the early historian Josephus (who had access to some sources we no longer have, but also had his own agenda and flawed standards of evidence), and possibly the Gnostic Gospels (some sects think it's the sin of heresy to read those, though).

After that sketchy early period, Roman records start to cover the emergenc

The information we have about the first few decades and even centuries after Jesus' crucifixion is spotty, but you can get an idea of the story from reading certain sources: the New Testament (especially Acts and the epistles), the writings of the early church fathers, the writings of the early historian Josephus (who had access to some sources we no longer have, but also had his own agenda and flawed standards of evidence), and possibly the Gnostic Gospels (some sects think it's the sin of heresy to read those, though).

After that sketchy early period, Roman records start to cover the emergence of this new religion called Christianity, its division into squabbling sects, its strange relationship with Judaism (a much better understood religion), and their claims of persection by Romans, by Jews, and by each other. It becomes a fad in certain Roman circles to convert to Christianity despite not understanding it well (it was fashionable for the very rich to pretend they didn't care about money, which might lead to conversion, real or pretended, to Stoicism or Christianity), and in other circles to have great debates about the minutia of Christianty.

Most new societies that joined (were conquered by) Rome added their gods to the Roman Pantheon, but Christians had this weird tendancy to treat that as sacrilegious. Also, Christians tended to call each other “brother” and “sister” but intermarry anyway, leading to accusations of incest. They also had a ceremony of drinking their God's blood and eating his flesh, like cannibals. So Romans had some serious misgivings about these weirdos.

Eventually, enough unrest arose from the Christian question that Emperor Constantine got representatives from all the Christian sects to get together, to try to figure out all of their squabbles, and to issue a joint statement of what all Christians believe both to end their sectional disputes and to inform greater Rome. There were a lot of meetings, most of which ended with large portions of the Christian community labelled as heretics or storming off amid condemnations of the whole enterprise.

But eventually, in Nicea in 325, an edict was issued declaring a basic tennant that most Christians could support as the basis of their faith. It was amended a couple times in subsequent councils, but generally defines what it means to be Christian. The Nicene Creed translates into English as something like:

We believe in one God, the Father Almighty, the maker of heaven and earth, of things visible and invisible.

And in one Lord Jesus Christ, the Son of God, the begotten of God the Father, the Only-begotten, that is of the essence of the Father.

God of God, Light of Light, true God of true God, begotten and not made; of the very same nature of the Father, by Whom all things came into being, in heaven and on earth, visible and invisible.

Who for us humanity and for our salvation came down from heaven, was incarnate, was made human, was born perfectly of the holy virgin Mary by the Holy Spirit.

By whom He took body, soul, and mind, and everything that is in man, truly and not in semblance.

He suffered, was crucified, was buried, rose again on the third day, ascended into heaven with the same body, and sat at the right hand of the Father.

He is to come with the same body and with the glory of the Father, to judge the living and the dead; of His kingdom there is no end.

We believe in the Holy Spirit, in the uncreated and the perfect; Who spoke through the Law, prophets, and Gospels; Who came down upon the Jordan, preached through the apostles, and lived in the saints.

We believe also in only One, Universal, Apostolic, and Holy Church; in one baptism in repentance, for the remission, and forgiveness of sins; and in the resurrection of the dead, in the everlasting judgement of souls and bodies, and the Kingdom of Heaven and in the everlasting life.

Emperor Constantine later declared Christianity as defined by this creed to be the official religion of the Roman Empire, thus establishing the Catholic (meaning universal) Church. On his deathbed, Constantine converted to Christianity himself, hedging his bets for the afterlife. Seeing as how Rome was the greatest power for a thousand miles in any direction, that pretty much culminated Christianity's rise.

Christianity fell into obscurity when Rome fell, in that it was the dominant religion in southern Europe, the Middle East, and northern Africa but those areas no longer stood as the dominant culture in the world (west of China, anyway). Christianity spread north during those dark ages, and though north Africa was conquered and eastern Christians separated from Europe by the rise of Islamic Caliphates, Christian Europe rose again to world prominance after the Enlightenment (roughly the 1400s) and the rise of nation-states and their global colonial empires (which were motivated in part by the Christian urge to bring the Christian Gospel to every people in the world).

And that pretty much gets us to today, give or take a few centuries.

Colin Jensen

Is a Temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints considered a Church?
Originally Answered: Is a Mormon Temple considered a Church?

No and yes. Mostly No.

We don't call it a church and we don't do things in there that we do in church (we don't meet as a group with whoever shows up from the community to sing or have gospel centered lessons or play basketball or attend a Boy Scout meeting.) But the things we do in the temple are things that others do in their churches (weddings, reflection/prayer/meditation.)

So no we don't consider it a church technically. But yes it is a religious building used for religious purposes, so we wouldn't be offended if, when playing SimCity, "temple" was just a leveled-up "church."
